TypeSignature.Value: .class public auto ansi sealed beforefieldinit LinearGradientBrush extends System.Windows.Media.GradientBrush
Public NotInheritable Class LinearGradientBrush Inherits GradientBrush
public ref class LinearGradientBrush sealed : System::Windows::Media::GradientBrush
.class public auto ansi sealed LinearGradientBrush extends System.Windows.Media.GradientBrush

Docs.summary: Paints an area with a linear gradient.

remarks.format:
## Remarks A <xref:System.Windows.Media.LinearGradientBrush> paints an area with a linear gradient. A linear gradient defines a gradient along a line. The line's end points are defined by the <xref:System.Windows.Media.LinearGradientBrush.StartPoint%2A> and <xref:System.Windows.Media.LinearGradientBrush.EndPoint%2A> properties of the linear gradient. A <xref:System.Windows.Media.LinearGradientBrush> brush paints its <xref:System.Windows.Media.GradientBrush.GradientStops%2A> along this line.
The default linear gradient is diagonal. In the default, the <xref:System.Windows.Media.LinearGradientBrush.StartPoint%2A> of a linear gradient is (0,0), the upper-left corner of the area being painted, and its <xref:System.Windows.Media.LinearGradientBrush.EndPoint%2A> is (1,1), the lower-right corner of the area being painted. The colors in the resulting gradient are interpolated along the diagonal path.
The following illustration shows a diagonal gradient. A line was added to highlight the interpolation path of the gradient from the start point to the end point.
![Gradient axis for a diagonal linear gradient](~/add/media/wcpsdk-graphicsmm-diagonalgradientaxis.png "Gradient axis for a diagonal linear gradient") A diagonal linear gradient
The next illustration shows the same linear gradient, but with highlighted gradient stops.
![Gradient stops in a linear gradient](~/add/media/wcpsdk-graphicsmm-4gradientstops.png "Gradient stops in a linear gradient") A diagonal linear gradient with highlighted gradient stops
It is possible to specify a gradient axis that does not completely fill area being painted. When this occurs, the <xref:System.Windows.Media.GradientBrush.SpreadMethod%2A> property determines how the remaining area is painted.
## Freezable Features A <xref:System.Windows.Media.LinearGradientBrush> is a type of <xref:System.Windows.Freezable> object and therefore can be frozen to improve performance. For information about <xref:System.Windows.Freezable> features, such as freezing and cloning, see [Freezable Objects Overview](~/docs/framework/wpf/advanced/freezable-objects-overview.md).

Docs.summary: Gets or sets the ending two-dimensional coordinates of the linear gradient.
Docs.value: The ending two-dimensional coordinates of the linear gradient. The default is (1,1).

remarks.format: ## Remarks A paints a gradient along a line. The line's start and end points are defined by the and properties of the . The default linear gradient is diagonal. In the default, the of a linear gradient is (0,0), the upper-left corner of the area being filled, and its is (1,1), the lower-right corner of the area being filled. The colors in the resulting gradient are interpolated along the diagonal path. The following image shows a diagonal gradient. The black line was added to highlight the interpolation path of the gradient from the start point to the end point. ![Gradient axis for a diagonal linear gradient](~/add/media/wcpsdk-graphicsmm-diagonalgradientaxis.png "Gradient axis for a diagonal linear gradient") A diagonal linear gradient ## Specifying Relative or Absolute Values Note that the property of a determines whether its is interpreted as a relative or absolute value. A of specifies that the value is relative to the size of the painted area. A of specifies that the value is expressed in device independent pixels. By default, the is set to , making the a relative value. ## Dependency Property Information ||| |-|-| |Identifier field|| |Metadata properties set to `true`|None|
